feature.name: SYNC
feature.label: Synchronization object (Sync)
feature.description:
The Sync Object is broadcast periodically by the Sync Producer.
Permissible value for SYNC is 0 or 1.

feature.name: Emergency
feature.label: Emergency object (Emcy)
feature.description:
The Emergency message is triggered by the occurrence of a device internal error situation.
Permissible value for Emergency is 0 or 1.

feature.name: SDO server
feature.label: Service Data Object (SDO)
feature.description:
A Service Data Object (SDO) reads from entries or writes to entries of the Object Dictionary. SDO server is implemented on all CANopen devices.
Permissible value for SDO sever is 0 or 1.

feature.name: SDO client
feature.label: Service Data Object (SDO)
feature.description:
A Service Data Object (SDO) reads from entries or writes to entries of the Object Dictionary. SDO client is usually a master device in a CANopen network.
Permissible value for SDO client is 0 or 1.

feature.name: RPDO
feature.label: Recive Process Data Object (RPDO)
feature.description:
Process Data Objects (PDOs) are mapped to a single CAN frame using up to 8 bytes of the data field to transmit application objects. Each PDO has a unique identifier and is transmitted by only one node, but it can be received by more than one (producer/consumer communication).
Permissible value for RPDO is 0 to 16. For larger value Max Index must be changed.

feature.name: TPDO
feature.label: Transmit Process Data Object (TPDO)
feature.description:
Process Data Objects (PDOs) are mapped to a single CAN frame using up to 8 bytes of the data field to transmit application objects. Each PDO has a unique identifier and is transmitted by only one node, but it can be received by more than one (producer/consumer communication).
Permissible value for TPDO is 0 to 16. For larger value Max Index must be changed.

feature.name: User CANRX
feature.label: User defined CAN receive objects
feature.description: User defined CAN object can be used for custom functionality of the device.

feature.name: User CANTX
feature.description: User defined CAN object can be used for custom functionality of the device.
feature.label: User defined CAN transmit objects

feature.name: Max object size
feature.label: Max object size
feature.description: Max object size is maximum size of object in Object Dictionary in bytes. Value can be in range from 4 to 255. If value is 4, then SDO server will be simplified, because it will only use expedited transfer and not segmented.

feature.name: Retentive usage
feature.label: Retentive Usage
feature.description:
This feature is CANopenNode specific. It defines the strategy, how retentive variables are managed on specific microcontroller.
Variables in Object Dictionary have different behavior. In general, variable can be one of the three types - RAM, EEPROM or ROM: - RAM variables: general use; on startup they have initial value; can be changed by application or from network side (by SDO communication). - EEPROM variables: retentive (value is retained, if power supply is disconnected); can be changed by application or from network side; access is fast; memory resources are limited; example use: counter of events. - ROM variables: retentive; can NOT be changed by application (directly); can be read normally by application; can be changed from network side; writing to variable takes some time; memory resources are large; example use: for configuration parameters.
On different chips there are different strategies, how to handle retentive variables. PIC and dsPIC flash devices have possibility to use flash (program) memory for variables. Flash can be reprogrammed in run-time, so 'ROM' variables are writeable. And NO RAM is used for them. On the other hand SC1xx chip (similar as PC) loads execution program in RAM memory and also all variables are there. 'ROM' variables are there saved in file system.
Values for macro CO_RETENTIVE_USE: 0 - NO retentive variables, EEPROM variables behaves like RAM. ROM variables are hard coded in flash, they are NOT changeable. 1 - NO retentive variables, EEPROM and ROM variables are allocated in RAM memory space, variables are changeable. 2 - EEPROM = default. ROM variables are hard coded in flash, they are NOT changeable. 3 - EEPROM = default. ROM variables are appended to EEPROM variables, they behaves like EEPROM and consumes also RAM on PICs and dsPICs. Take special care, if there is enough EEPROM memory. 4 - EEPROM = default. ROM = default. Flash is updated each time when ROM variable is written from network side. In PICs and dsPICs no RAM is used for ROM variables. 5 - EEPROM = default. ROM variables are stored in RAM. Flash is updated, when 'Save all Parameters' is performed (Write "save" to OD, index 0x1010, subindex 0x01). Restoring default parameters is also possible. 6 - EEPROM variables behaves like RAM, are not retentive. ROM = default. Flash is updated each time when ROM variable is written from network side. In PICs and dsPICs no RAM is used for ROM variables. 7 - EEPROM variables behaves like RAM, are not retentive. ROM variables are stored in RAM. Flash is updated, when 'Save all Parameters' is performed (Write "save" to OD, index 0x1010, subindex 0x01). Restoring default parameters is also possible.
Recommendations and possibilities on different chips: - PIC18F: 4=recommended, possible: 0, 1, 2, 3(conditional), 6 - dsPIC30F: 4=recommended, possible: 0, 1, 2, 3(conditional), 6 - dsPIC33F, PIC24H: 3=recommended (with external serial EEPROM chip), 7=possible, but only 1000 writings is allowed, other possibilities: 0, 1, (2, 5(with external serial EEPROM chip)) - Beck SC1x: 5=recommended, possible: 0, 1, 2, 3(not recommended), 7

feature.name: RPDO usage
feature.label: RDPO usage
feature.description:
Process Data Objects (or PDOs) are used for fast communication between CANopen (and also between simple CAN) devices. In general, they are CAN messages with specific CAN identifier, which are sending some specified application data.
CANopen standard offers very flexible usage of Process Data Objects. With PDO Communication Parameters specifies CAN ID and rules, when and how message will be transmitted (or received). PDO mapping parameters specifies, which variables from Object Dictionary will be in the message body.
CANopenNode offers full support for Process Data Objects. Ammount of functionality is configurable.
Transmission types: Synchronous, with Event timer, integrated inhibit time. Reception and transmission of PDOs is automatic. If CO_xPDO_USAGE >= 7, then PDO data are automatically copied to/from OD variables. (Memory type of those OD variables must be RAM.)
Also if CO_TPDO_USAGE >= 7, then special type of OD variable can be used for TPDO send request. This variable contains (besides its own data) also a list of TPDOs, into which this variable is mapped. So application can report Change of State or just request sending of TPDO, into which variable is mapped (if it is). Usage is following: First determine, when variable needs to be sent, and second call a function ODE_VariableName_requestTPDO(), where VariableName is name of the variable. (Variable data are accessed with ODE_VariableName). Some limitations: It works only on the first 16 TPDOs and it does not work on subindexes. (Does not work on objects where Object Type is array or record.)
Values for macro CO_xPDO_USAGE (x is either R or T) (Larger number means more functionality and more memory used.): 1 - Communication parameters are read-only. 2 - Communication parameters are changeable. PDO behavior is changed after Communication reset. 3 - Communication parameters are changeable. PDO behavior is changed immediately after writing to parameter. 1, 2, 3 - Mapping parameters does not exist. Length of RPDO data is any, length of TPDO is 8 bytes. Length of TPDO can can be changed directly with writing to variable: CO_TXCAN[i+CO_TXCAN_TPDO].NoOfBytes
4 - Communication parameters are read-only. 5 - Communication parameters are changeable. PDO behavior is changed after Communication reset. 6 - Communication parameters are changeable. PDO behavior is changed immediately after writing to parameter. 4, 5, 6 - Mapping parameters are read-only. Length of xPDO is calculated from Mapping. PDO data are NOT automatically copied to/from OD variables.
7 - Communication parameters are read-only. 8 - Communication parameters are changeable. PDO behavior is changed after Communication reset. 9 - Communication parameters are changeable. PDO behavior is changed immediately after writing to parameter. 7, 8, 9 - Mapping parameters are read-only. Length of xPDO is calculated from Mapping. PDO data are automatically copied to/from OD variables.
10 - Communication and Mapping parameters are changeable. Mapping is dynamic. PDO behavior is changed after Communication reset. 11 - Communication and Mapping parameters are changeable. Mapping is dynamic. PDO behavior is changed immediately after writing to parameter.

CANopenObject.name: Device type
CANopenObject.label: Device type
CANopenObject.description: bit 0-15: Device profile number bit 16-31: Additional information

CANopenObject.name: Error register
CANopenObject.label: Error register
CANopenObject.description: bit 0: generic error bit 1: current bit 2: voltage bit 3: temperature bit 4: communication error (overrun, error state) bit 5: device profile specific bit 6: Reserved (always 0) bit 7: manufacturer specific

CANopenObject.name: Manufacturer status register
CANopenObject.label: Manufacturer status register
CANopenObject.description: bit 0-31: Not used by stack (available for user)

CANopenObject.name: Pre-defined error field
CANopenObject.label: Pre-defined error field
CANopenObject.description:
Number of Errors bit 0-7: Zero can be written to erase error history
Standard Error Field bit 0-15: Error code as transmited in the Emergency object bit 16-31: Manufacturer specific additional information

CANopenObject.name: COB-ID SYNC message
CANopenObject.label: COB-ID SYNC message
CANopenObject.description: bit 0-10: COB-ID for SYNC object bit 11-29: set to 0 bit 30: 1(0) - node generates (does NOT generate) SYNC object bit 31: set to 0

CANopenObject.name: Communication cycle period
CANopenObject.label: Communication cycle period
CANopenObject.description: bit 0-31: period of SYNC transmission in µs (0 = no transmission, no checking)

CANopenObject.name: Synchronous window length
CANopenObject.label: Synchronous window length
CANopenObject.description: bit 0-31: window leghth after SYNC when PDOS must be transmited in µs, (0 = not used)

CANopenObject.name: Manufacturer device name
CANopenObject.label: Manufacturer device name
CANopenObject.description: Name of the manufacturer as string

CANopenObject.name: Manufacturer hardware version
CANopenObject.label: Manufacturer hardware version
CANopenObject.description: Name of the hardware version as string

CANopenObject.name: Manufacturer software version
CANopenObject.label: Manufacturer software version
CANopenObject.description: Name of the software version as string.

CANopenObject.name: COB-ID EMCY
CANopenObject.label: COB-ID emergency message
CANopenObject.description: bit 0-10: COB-ID bit 11-30: set to 0 for 11 bit COB-ID bit 31: 0(1) - node uses (does NOT use) Emergency object

CANopenObject.name: inhibit time EMCY
CANopenObject.label: inhibit time emergency message
CANopenObject.description: bit 0-15: Inhibit time of emergency message in 100µs

CANopenObject.name: Consumer heartbeat time
CANopenObject.label: Consumer heartbeat time
CANopenObject.description:
max sub-index
Consumer Heartbeat Time bit 0-15: Heartbeat consumer time in ms (0 = node is not monitored) bit 16-23: Node ID bit 24-31: set to 0

CANopenObject.name: Producer heartbeat time
CANopenObject.label: Producer heartbeat time
CANopenObject.description: bit 0-15: Heartbeat producer time in ms (0 = disable transmission)

CANopenObject.name: Identity
CANopenObject.label: Identity
CANopenObject.description:
max sub-index
Vendor-ID bit 0-31: Assigned by CiA
Product code bit 0-31: Manufacturer specific
Revision number bit 0-15: Minor revision num. (CANopen behavior has not changed) bit 16-31: Major revision number (CANopen behavior has changed)
Serial number bit 0-31: Manufacturer specific

CANopenObject.name: Error behavior
CANopenObject.label: Error behavior
CANopenObject.description:
max sub-index
Communication error bit 0-7: If Error Register (0x1001) has Communication error bit set and device is in Operational state: 0x00-switch to pre-operational 0x01-do nothing 0x02-switch to stopped

CANopenObject.name: SDO server parameter
CANopenObject.label: SDO server parameter
CANopenObject.description:
0x1200 SDO server parameter max sub-index
COB-ID client to server (Receive SDO) bit 0-31: 0x00000600 + Node ID
COB-ID server to client (Transmit SDO) bit 0-31: 0x00000580 + Node ID
0x1201 - 0x127F SDO server parameter max sub-index
COB-ID client to server (Receive SDO) bit 0-10: COB_ID bit 11-30: Set to 0 bit 31*: 0(1) - node uses (does NOT use) SDO
COB-ID server to client (Transmit SDO) bit 0-31: same as previous
Node-ID of the SDO client bit 0-7: Node ID (optional)

CANopenObject.name: SDO client parameter
CANopenObject.label: SDO client parameter
CANopenObject.description:
0x1280 - 0x12FF SDO client parameter max sub-index
COB-ID client to server (Transmit SDO) bit 0-10: COB_ID bit 11-30: Set to 0 bit 31: 0(1) - node uses (does NOT use) SDO
COB-ID server to client (Receive SDO) bit 0-31: same as previous
Node-ID of the SDO server 0-7: Node ID

CANopenObject.name: RPDO communication parameter
CANopenObject.label: RPDO communication parameter
CANopenObject.description:
0x1400 - 0x15FF RPDO communication parameter max sub-index
COB-ID bit 0-10: COB-ID for PDO, to change it bit 31 must be set bit 11-29: set to 0 for 11 bit COB-ID bit 30: 0(1) - rtr are allowed (are NOT allowed) for PDO bit 31: 0(1) - node uses (does NOT use) PDO
Transmission type value = 0-240: reciving is synchronous, process after next reception of SYNC object value = 241-253: not used value = 254: manufacturer specific value = 255: asynchronous

CANopenObject.name: RPDO communication parameter
CANopenObject.label: RPDO communication parameter
CANopenObject.description: 0x1400 - 0x15FF RPDO communication parameter (see description for 0x1400)

CANopenObject.name: RPDO communication parameter
CANopenObject.label: RPDO communication parameter
CANopenObject.description: 0x1400 - 0x15FF RPDO communication parameter (see description for 0x1400)

CANopenObject.label: RPDO communication parameter
CANopenObject.description: 0x1400 - 0x15FF RPDO communication parameter (see description for 0x1400)

CANopenObject.name: RPDO communication parameter
CANopenObject.label: RPDO communication parameter
CANopenObject.description: 0x1400 - 0x15FF RPDO communication parameter (see description for 0x1400)

CANopenObject.name: RPDO mapping parameter
CANopenObject.label: RPDO mapping parameter
CANopenObject.description:
0x1600 - 0x17FF RPDO mapping parameter (To change mapping, max sub-index must be set to 0) max sub-index
mapped object (subindex 1...8) bit 0-7: data length in bits bit 8-15: subindex from OD bit 16-31: index from OD

CANopenObject.name: RPDO mapping parameter
CANopenObject.label: RPDO mapping parameter
CANopenObject.description: 0x1600 - 0x17FF RPDO mapping parameter (see description for 0x1600)

CANopenObject.name: RPDO mapping parameter
CANopenObject.label: RPDO mapping parameter
CANopenObject.description: 0x1600 - 0x17FF RPDO mapping parameter (see description for 0x1600)

CANopenObject.name: RPDO mapping parameter
CANopenObject.label: RPDO mapping parameter
CANopenObject.description: 0x1600 - 0x17FF RPDO mapping parameter (see description for 0x1600)

CANopenObject.name: RPDO mapping parameter
CANopenObject.label: RPDO mapping parameter
CANopenObject.description: 0x1600 - 0x17FF RPDO mapping parameter (see description for 0x1600)

CANopenObject.name: TPDO communication parameter
CANopenObject.label: TPDO communication parameter
CANopenObject.description:
0x1800 - 0x19FF TPDO communication parameter max sub-index
COB-ID bit 0-10: COB-ID for PDO, to change it bit 31 must be set bit 11-29: set to 0 for 11 bit COB-ID bit 30: 0(1) - rtr are allowed (are NOT allowed) for PDO bit 31: 0(1) - node uses (does NOT use) PDO
Transmission type value = 0: transmiting is synchronous, specification in device profile value = 1-240: transmiting is synchronous after every N-th SYNC object value = 241-251: not used value = 252-253: Transmited only on reception of Remote Transmission Request value = 254: manufacturer specific value = 255: asinchronous, specification in device profile
inhibit time bit 0-15: Minimum time between transmissions of the PDO in 100µs. Zero disables functionality.
compatibility entry bit 0-7: Not used.
event timer bit 0-15: Time between periodic transmissions of the PDO in ms. Zero disables functionality.

CANopenObject.name: TPDO communication parameter
CANopenObject.label: TPDO communication parameter
CANopenObject.description: 0x1800 - 0x19FF TPDO communication parameter (see description for 0x1800)

CANopenObject.name: TPDO communication parameter
CANopenObject.label: TPDO communication parameter
CANopenObject.description: 0x1800 - 0x19FF TPDO communication parameter (see description for 0x1800)

CANopenObject.name: TPDO communication parameter
CANopenObject.label: TPDO communication parameter
CANopenObject.description: 0x1800 - 0x19FF TPDO communication parameter (see description for 0x1800)

CANopenObject.name: TPDO communication parameter
CANopenObject.label: TPDO communication parameter
CANopenObject.description: 0x1800 - 0x19FF TPDO communication parameter (see description for 0x1800)

CANopenObject.name: TPDO mapping parameter
CANopenObject.label: TPDO mapping parameter
CANopenObject.description:
0x1A00 - 0x1BFF TPDO mapping parameter (To change mapping, max sub-index must be set to 0) max sub-index
mapped object (subindex 1...8) bit 0-7: data length in bits bit 8-15: subindex from OD bit 16-31: index from OD

CANopenObject.name: TPDO mapping parameter
CANopenObject.label: TPDO mapping parameter
CANopenObject.description: 0x1A00 - 0x1BFF TPDO mapping parameter (see description for 0x1A00)

CANopenObject.name: TPDO mapping parameter
CANopenObject.label: TPDO mapping parameter
CANopenObject.description: 0x1A00 - 0x1BFF TPDO mapping parameter (see description for 0x1A00)

CANopenObject.name: TPDO mapping parameter
CANopenObject.label: TPDO mapping parameter
CANopenObject.description: 0x1A00 - 0x1BFF TPDO mapping parameter (see description for 0x1A00)

CANopenObject.name: TPDO mapping parameter
CANopenObject.label: TPDO mapping parameter
CANopenObject.description: 0x1A00 - 0x1BFF TPDO mapping parameter (see description for 0x1A00)

CANopenObject.name: NMT startup
CANopenObject.label: NMT Startup
CANopenObject.description:
Only bit 2 is implemented.
bit 0: 0(1) - device is not (is) NMT master bit 1: 0(1) - if bit3=0, start explicitly assigned (all) nodes bit 2: 0(1) - automaticaly enter (DO NOT automaticaly enter) the operational state on bootup bit 3: 0(1) - NMT master may (may not) start nodes automatically bit 4: 0(1) - if monitored node fails heartbeat handle that (all) node(s) bit 5: 0(1) - flying master process not (yes) supported bit 6: 0(1) - use bit 4 (ignore bit 4, stop all nodes) bit 7-31: reserved, set to 0

CANopenObject.name: Error status bits
CANopenObject.label: Error Status Bits
CANopenObject.description: Error Status Bits indicates any error occurred in program. Specific bit is set by ErrorReport() function, when error occurs in program. It can be reset by ErrorReset() function, if error is solved. On each change of any Error Status Bit Emergency message is sent. If critical bits are set, node will not be able to enter operational state. For more information see file CO_errors.h.

CANopenObject.name: CAN node ID
CANopenObject.label: CAN Node ID
CANopenObject.description:
CAN Node ID is CANopenNode specific variable. It sets node-ID for device on CANopen network. Node-ID can be set on other ways too, for example with DIP switches. More advanced solution is use of LSS.
Valid values are from 1 to 127:

CANopenObject.name: CAN bit rate
CANopenObject.label: CAN Bit-Rate
CANopenObject.description:
CAN Bit-Rate is CANopenNode specific variable. It sets CAN Bit-Rate for device on CANopen network. Bit-Rate can be set on other ways too, for example with DIP switches. More advanced solution is use of LSS.
Valid values are from 0 to 7: 0 = 10 kbps 1 = 20 kbps 2 = 50 kbps 3 = 125 kbps 4 = 250 kbps 5 = 500 kbps 6 = 800 kbps 7 = 1000 kbps

CANopenObject.name: SYNC counter
CANopenObject.label: SYNC Counter
CANopenObject.description: SYNC Counter is incremented each time, SYNC message is received or transmitted.

CANopenObject.name: SYNC time
CANopenObject.label: SYNC Time
CANopenObject.description: SYNC Time is incremented each timer period and reset to zero, each time SYNC is received or transmitted.

CANopenObject.name: Performance
CANopenObject.label: Performance
CANopenObject.description: Microcontroller Performance is measured automatically by stack. It gives some information, how much is microcontroller loaded and if it runs smoothly.

CANopenObject.name: Power-on counter
CANopenObject.label: Power on Counter
CANopenObject.description: Power on Counter counts total microcontroller resets in it's lifetime. Variable is an example of EEPROM usage.

productText.label: CANopenNode
productText.description: CANopenNode is an open source software stack used for serial communication of multiple devices over the CAN/CANopen Network. It runs on different microcontrollers, is reliable, simple and powerful and is suitable for industrial or home automation.
